Q: What effect does reading the play have on its readers?
A:
Reading the play produces a powerful, disturbing effect: readers experience intense emotion — “with a cry of terror, or perhaps it was of joy so poignant that I suffered in every nerve” — and may be compelled to stop and even destroy the book (flinging it into the fireplace). The work's later part is treated as taboo: many “refused to listen,” were deterred by the “wicked pages” and “never ventured to discuss the second part aloud.”
